div.sent: Gautama Buddha advised the Bhikkhus at different times on various topics.
He proclaimed His doctrine to the laities too.
He recited the Sutras and explained them to the attendants.
Where and on what occasion these Sutras were manifested have been mentioned in the holy Tripitakas.
Nidhikanda Sutra includes in the Khuddaka Patho of the Sutrapitaka.
Once the Buddha was residing at Sravasti along with the Bhikkhu Sangha.
A rich merchant of that place showed his devotion and respect to the Buddha.
He often invited the Buddha with His disciples.
The merchant was very much wealthy.
He led an honest life.
All of a sudden, the king of the country was in need of money.
The king said to one of his attendants, Go to the merchant and ask him to come to me.
The attendants went to the merchant and said, The king has asked you to meet him.
At that very moment the merchant was engaged in serving the Buddha with food.
The merchant then said to the royal messenger, You please go now, I shall meet him later on.
I am now sowing the seeds of wealth.
Saying so, he again began to serve the Buddha and the Bhikkhu Sangha.
Saying so the Buddha recited the Nidhikanda Sutra.
The Pali word Nidhi means wealth.
The wealth is of two kinds--quantitative and qualitative.
Money, gold, diamond etc. are quantitative wealth while knowledge, wisdom and other virtues are the wealth of quality.
Kanda denotes the stem or the root of the plants.
So the meaning of Nidhikanda is the root of wealth kept hidden underground.
The virtues attained by human being follow him in the present and preceding lives.
This is the reason that the wealth of virtues is called the real wealth or nidhi.
Both money and wealth may be stolen or misappropriated by others.
Again this kind of wealth may be destroyed due to famine, flood or fire.
Even the king of the state may cease the wealth.
But the virtues earned by charity might never be wasted.
These virtues follow the person even in the next world after death.
So these virtues are the real wealth of human being.
We should try our best to earn these real virtues.
Money is necessary for livelihood.
Both money and wealth are further required to lead our mortal life.
But this kind of wealth is useless after death.
Man is reborn as soon as he dies.
To be born in a noble family we should earn the virtues.
These virtues are gained by founding the monastery and shrine.
Service to parents and the superiors help us earn the virtues.
Moreover, service to the poor and the sick bring happiness in our life.
The Nidhikanda Sutra will lead us to attain all these virtues.
Will this be helpful at the time of scarcity- thinking so the people keep their wealth into the deep cavity underground.
For saving from persecution of the ruler, stealing by the thief, debt, famine and danger, the people keep their wealth hidden underground.
In the nick of time the wealth put underground seldom brings good return.
This wealth of virtues can be claimed by none nor it be stolen by the thief.
So should the wise try their best to attain the virtues that follow them.
This wealth of virtues fulfils all desires of both men and deities and helps attain everything as prayed for.
Attracting colour, sweet voice.
healthy body, handsome face, sovereign lordship and noble family, all these qualities may be attained with the virtues earned.
30 Buddhist Religious Studies Predominance of the kingdom, the glory, the imperial happiness, divine contentment etc. are attained by proper application of the wealth.
Human excellence, heavenly pleasure and the happiness of Nibbana are attained with this virtue.
On attainment of this wealth he who perform, meditation with noble intention can achieve the skill, salvation and mental satisfaction.
The proper utilisation of wealth helps the owner to attain analytical knowledge, deliverance, perfection or Arahantship, self-Enlightenment and the Buddhahood.
These virtues are so supernatural that are appreciated by the learned ofprofound knowledge.
The Pali word Appamada means heedfulness, rightfulness or resolute and Vagga refers to the chapter or episode.
Here the actual meaning of Appamada is the interest to perform right activities faithfully.
So the righteous persons always perform their activities with self control and great devotion.
The devoted persons attain Nibbana conquering the cycle of birth and rebirth.
They remain immortal.
On the other hand the reckless are as same as the deceased.
Because they cannot control themselves.
So they are under control of birth and rebirth.
They can never attain Nibbana.
The Appamada Vagga has been taken from the Dhammapada.
It is a part of the Tripitaka.
There are more 25 vaggas like it i.e. the Dhammapada contains 26 vaggas.

Shyamavati had great devotion to the Buddha while Magandhia was envious to Him.
Magandhia out of malice burnt Shyamavati to death along with her five hundred associates.
Devadatta who was also envious to Buddha tried always to endanger His life.
Devadatta appointed some expert archers with the help of the king Ajatsatru to kill the Buddha.
One of the best archers, shooted an arrow to the Buddha but surprisingly it came back.
After the incident he begged pardon and became the disciple of the Buddha along with all the members of his gang.
Later on Devadatta tried to kill the Buddha by throwing a heavy stone from a high hill.
Once again Devadatta set Nalagiri, a very large elephant intoxicating him with wine for killing the Buddha.
But the Buddha could save Himself twice by virtue of His amity and compassion.
Atlast Devadatta losing all his honour and prestige wanted to undertake refuge to the Buddha.
But he could not see the Buddha.
The earth split up and took him into the hell.
Pamada i.e. the heedlessness destroys completely the human life.
So the heedlessness should be avoided.
Asoka became the emperor by killing his 99 brothers.
Later, he fought against Kalinga (Orissa).
In this fight one and a half lac of people were killed.
The bloodshed of the battle field brought an unprecedented change in his life.
He became a heedful emperor.
He took the vow to conquer the countries with amity instead of fighting.
He embraced Buddhism taking ordination to Bhikkhu Upagupta.
Since then Asoka ruled over the subjects with heedfulness through out his life.
He stressed to live a virtuous life.
He prohibitted killing animals.
He observed heedfulness as the best wealth till his death.
Everybody should therefore, dedicate himself to lead a heedful life.
It is possible to establish our life avoiding all sorts of heedlessness.
